column4: Any idea why when I do any configs via the CLI GUI the thing is borked? http://x01.ath.cx:81/temp/distort.png
Any idea why when I do any configs via the CLI GUI the thing is borked? http://x01.ath.cx:81/temp/distort.png - I just fixed the link
cli gui?
Scratch that. Look at the link I pasted. It says what I'm talking about - thanks
how is it borked?
uh, look at the screen shot. See all those distorted characters?
oh! what terminal are you using?
# echo $TERM
heh, that's probably the problem
inside of what term?
rxvt
i know that i've had problems with some apps looking nasty like that inside of screen in rxvt
my suggestion is screen inside of xterm
I was having issues with xterm
what issues?
Well, not really issues.. I couldn't find a way to increase the font size.
here's a nice font. just a second
insert these two lines in your .Xresources
It was just too small and hard on the eyes
you can set the facesize to whatever you want
thanks
I don't have that file on my system, where do I put it
put those into /home/foo/.Xresources
thanks
and then do xrdb -merge ~/.Xresources
you might also want to insert this one so you can use alt
XTerm*metaSendsEscape: true
thanks, you're awesome.
and this one will give it a nice title:  XTerm*title:           Ubuntu Terminal
*blush* thanks
why do you ask?
Because I want to install it :)
do "which mail"
did you see anything?
hm, that returns nothing ... it only works if I have it installed :P
lol. try installing mailutils
sudo aptitude install mailutils
hm, I use apt-get. Is there a difference.
well, there is.. but, why aptitude? Hm

aptitude is better with dependencies. if a program wants 20 other packages to be installed, but later you uninstall that package, aptitude will know to uninstall any of its dependencies that are no longer used
whereas apt-get will not
plus, it has a neater name
and mail is in mailutils
*sweet* I've had this issue before. Does it work the same as apt-get basically? (aptitude remove, install, --purge.. )
yup!
woohoo! Thanks for making it convenient guys!
and if you just do *sudo aptitude* it will give you a nice console gui
np!
Nice
hm, maybe I should make a symlink from apt-get to aptitude, it's habit. hehe.
i don't think that's a good idea...sorry
now, maybe if first you did this:
it's ok. hm, ok. I guess other programs can call on apt-get or something
actually, nm, i just wouldn't mess with changing apt-get...
it's dangeous to turn that off...
Haha, you're still around? I use sudo so much. Hmm. It should still work, though ..
i'm sick, and i've been off and on all day b/c i've nothing better to do right now
ah
why do you need to not have a password?
I'm setting something up and using sudo a lot.
sudo passwd root
su root
? I know, but that's not what I asked :/
i'm just saying you won't have to worry about this problem
Right, but it works on every other distro.
sudo apt-get install fluxbox
(you may need to enable universe repositories)
Hehe, yeah. Ok. I didn't know if ubuntu had some trick or something
:-). you just need to install it and then start if from the gdm
ah, thanks.
np
Was it you who told me to put XTerm*fontSize:             20 in .Xdefaults if I want to change the font size in my xterm?
hmmm, Xterm*fontSize         somenumber, yes
wait
it's actually Xterm*faceSize
*and without the capital X
hmm. Not working
I'll try that, thanks
hmmmm....well, good luck
hm, no luck. Any other ideas?
well, what's your font line in .Xresources? also, are you doing xrdb -merge ~/.Xresources?
xTerm*faceSize:             20 .. and I'm just restarting x. hmm
oh. well, the xrdb thing is easier, haha. and what's the faceName line?
That's all I have. hmm, what do you mean? I just want to up the font. hmm
hmm. 20 may be too big
Hmm. ok, I'll try 12. It was just for testing purposes.
Do I need to do that xrdb -merge ~/.Xresources ? Or what?
couldn't hurt...
i also have this line:  xterm*faceName:        MiscFixed
to give me a gnome-terminal-like font
It's in .Xdefaults.. do I need to put this in .Xresources?
ehhhh...i don't know. probably not then. i'm sorry, but i have to go.
hm, thanks.
